TALK.START.PARA: —When I was speaking before lunch, I said that I entirely agreed with the broad thrust of this defence White Paper. It is a line of approach that I have been advocating for many years-that is, that the Australian Defence Force should be structured around the tasks that we might have to do on our own, rather than, as happened in the past, being regarded as contributors to allied forces.

SPEECH.PARA: That sort of allied force approach has all sorts of problems. I will give just one example. In 1974, when we were still responsible for the defence of Papua New Guinea, honourable senators might remember, there was a near revolt there over mining royalties. There was a suggestion that Bougainville might separate from Papua New Guinea. We could scarcely give independence to Papua New Guinea when it was in a state of disintegration. The chiefs of staff were asked whether, if the Government wanted them to, they could put a battalion or so into Bougainville. The answer was: `Well, we have no amphibious assault capability. We have no airborne assault capability. So, if you are to put a force into Bougainville'-in each case the chief of staff was assuming that it would be done by somebody else in the allied forces-`it can be done only if the airfield is firmly held in friendly hands'. That is obviously a great limitation on our being able to do the things that we might have to do on our own. From that point of view, I entirely accept the structure and the purpose of this defence White Paper.

One thing that we must always keep in mind is that, although that is the way that our Defence Force should be structured, it is not necessarily the only way in which it will be used. It must be so trained, equipped and organised that it can co-operate with allies in appropriate operations, if called upon to do so. That aspect was badly under-emphasised in the Dibb report. The Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley), in the White Paper, has rectified that to some extent. It must always be an aim that we structure our force on what we must do on our own, but always keeping in mind that defence forces must be flexible and we might want to use them in co-operation with allies, so they must be organised, trained and equipped for that.

The second point I was making before lunch was that the assessment is that about 2.9 per cent of gross domestic product is all that will be available for defence unless there is an obvious and urgent threat. We should be spending more. But I do not believe in the current economic situation that it would be realistic to plan on more. If we in opposition promised to provide a great deal more for defence, we would not be believed. If we went into office with such a promise, we would not deliver. We have to look at our defence planning in realistic terms, and that is the sort of limit that we have to look at. So, if we want to suggest that things not proposed in the White Paper to be done should be done, we have to say what in the White Paper we think should be left out or where savings could be made; otherwise we are not being realistic.

In any case, I am very doubtful whether the capital program listed in the defence White Paper can be met within the resources available. It may be met; but it seems to me to be extremely doubtful, particularly as the White Paper, in quite a number of areas, is very vague about quantities and even acquisitions. For instance, it just states: `Some airborne warning and control aircraft will be provided'. How many and what sort is not even discussed. In that sense I am very doubtful whether the capital program can be met within the resources available. My great fear is that the Government will try to meet the capital program and, in order to make the resources available, will cut back on the running costs of the Defence Force. That is a way of getting quick reductions in defence expenditure, but it is a very unwise method. If we cut back on flying time or on steaming time for ships, or reduce the ammunition allowance for practice, what happens is what has been happening in recent years: We have an outflow of trained people who no longer get any professional satisfaction from sitting around doing second rate tasks. If we want to keep trained, efficient people interested in the Services, we must give them the chance to practice their profession. Regrettably, these days that costs a great deal of money.

As I have said, if we want to suggest changes, we must suggest where savings could be made. I have a few suggestions which seem to me to involve no cost or which might even make some modest savings. I am delighted to see that a Vice-Chief of the Defence Force has been appointed, to centralise forward equipment programming in particular. The worst aspect of our defence planning has been the way in which delegates from each Service have gone along to committee meetings, each fighting for his own Service and for a bigger share of the available capital resources, knowing that, if somebody else gets something, it will mean less in the pool for him. The conflict has been very bad for proper forward planning for the Australian Defence Force.

I give one example: Admirable though the FA18 aircraft is, I am quite sure that, if the capital requirements of the Defence Force had been looked at as a whole-what we want, how much capital we have and what sort of Defence Force we want overall-the FA18 would not have been purchased. That is the sort of difficult decision that has to be made and I hope that the Vice-Chief of the Defence Force will get together all the forward equipment planning people from the separate Services and tell the three Service chiefs to get on with running their Services with the equipment that they have. The forward planning must be done by the Defence Force as a whole.

Incidentally, I think the name `chiefs of staff' is very old fashioned and inappropriate. The Minister is very pleased that he called the Chief of the Defence Force by that title because that is what he is. The three Service chiefs should be called `Commander, Navy', `Commander, Army' and `Commander, Air Force'. They are not chiefs of staff in any meaningful sense and it is an absurdly archaic title. That is the first thing that we must do: We must get our forward equipment program centralised and looked at from the point of view of a defence force as a whole and not separate, rival Services.

The next thing that we should do, and I am sure that this would save money, is to re-organise the Department of Defence. It is an administrative shambles. The ancient Greeks had a saying: `Give mine enemy a golden sword'. A modern version might be: `Give mine enemy an organisation like the Australian Defence Department'. It is very, very unsatisfactory. It is grossly overmanned. There are more than 100 Second Division public servants in the Defence Department-and they are the expensive ones. The Department is structured very much on a sort of confrontation between the civil side and the professional side. I give just one instance, but there are many. We now have a Vice-Chief of the Defence Force charged with the forward planning of defence equipment and development. There is a division-a very appropriate one-called the Force Development and Analysis Division. One would think that that would come under the Vice-Chief of the Defence Force, but it does not. It quite separately reports to the civil chain so that that side will have some ammunition to shoot down, if it can, the professional proposals. It is a method of confrontation that does not make for efficient administration.

The third no-cost reform that we could make would be to get our senior Service officers into a proper balance between operational appointments and administrative appointments, a very high proportion of which are in the Department of Defence Central Office. For instance, I am looking at commodores, so-called rear-admirals and vice-admirals, and the equivalent officers in the other Services. The Royal Australian Navy has 41, the Australian Army has 60 and the Royal Australian Air Force has 41. The Navy has one admiral, 13 rear-admirals and 27 commodores. There is one sea job for one rear-admiral. The thing is ludicrously out of balance. How that came about was that when the Defence Department was amalgamated-something with which I entirely agree, by the way-in the report the public servants gave themselves quasi-military ranks. A lowly assistant secretary is rated as a brigadier, a first assistant secretary is rated as a major-general, a deputy secretary is rated as a lieutenant-general, and the Secretary rates himself very highly indeed-he is prepared to accept the rank of general. That may be laughable but the problem is that it meant that whenever a lowly assistant secretary was put on a committee the representatives from the three Services had to be a brigadier, a commodore and an air commodore, which caused this explosion in the senior ranks.

As I said earlier, the Royal Australian Navy now has one vice-admiral, 13 rear-admirals, 27 commodores and 15,000 men. It fought the Second World War with three admirals, four commodores and 45,000 men. We must get the senior ranks in the Services into balance in operational appointments and non-operational appointments, otherwise we will find ourselves with a very large number of people with no recent professional experience. To think that they are reserves for war time is so absurd that it is impossible to discuss because the last thing we would want in wartime would be senior officers who have not been to sea or who in the Army have not been operational for many years. Those are the modifications that we can make with no cost and perhaps with some modest cost savings.

If the White Paper is implemented the Australian Defence Force will not be able, firstly, to project our Army power to the perimeter of our area of interest. We have no amphibious capability. We have no significant airborne capability and, in any case, the Senate Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence was told that no thought of the possibility of overseas deployment plays any part in the structure of our ready reaction force. I can imagine many circumstances where it would be very much in Australia's interests not to involve itself in a prolonged major war but to send a quick reactionary force-a battalion or two-to help a friendly government retain control. We are not trying to impose a government on anyone else, and we certainly would not send a force unless we were welcome, but I think that our interests would be greatly assisted if we had available the forces and the means of deploying them so that they could be available if the Government so decided. In my view it is a disaster that we are allowing our amphibious capability to be dissipated, run down and ultimately destroyed.

This also rises a matter which is much more difficult and expensive-the ludicrous decision of the present Government to destroy the fixed wing Fleet Air Arm. It will make it very difficult for us to operate on the perimeter of our sphere of interest without fixed wing aircraft at sea. As far as I am concerned, there are only two rules of war. The first rule of war is do not march on Moscow, and the second rule of war is that a fleet that goes into an air attack area relying on shore-based aircraft is doomed. I think we should remember those as being important principles of war. The first principle does not have much to do with us but the second principle is very relevant to our present shortcomings.

The second deficiency that I see in the present proposed structure is that it is assumed that logistic support of forces in the north of Australia will be entirely overland. That has certain advantages but, in terms of fuel, it is an extremely costly way of supporting a force. We must remember that in the next 10 years we will be down to about 40 per cent self-sufficiency in oil. We must look at economies. The obvious way to support a force on distant coastlines like our northern coastline is by sea. To suggest that we do not need to provide for that and that overland support can be provided ignores the future of our oil supplies.

The third deficiency or criticism is that it seems to me that a great deal too much emphasis is being placed on the over the horizon radar. It may work and it may achieve the objectives and the claims that are being made about it, but it is still very much in the development stage. It has severe deficiencies, particularly with the detection of surface craft and aircraft moving at right angles to the beam. Although it may be very valuable, it is not a complete answer. We urgently need airborne early warning and control aircraft, and to put them in as merely possibles that might be provided gives them far too low a priority.

The next point I would like to make relates not really to a deficiency but is a matter which has been much argued about-the question of the defence of our seaborne trade. I always have difficulty about this. Having been in the Navy I am very seized of the importance of our seaborne trade. The sort of war we are talking about is not a global non-nuclear war-to my mind such a war is totally inconceivable-but presumably a bilateral war between Australia and someone else in the region, and under those circumstances one has to think what could affect our seaborne trade. The first thing we have to consider is that nearly all ships operate under a foreign flag. There is absolutely no way in which foreign ships would come to Australia and place themselves in Australian convoys. They just would not do it. They would come here with flags flying and lights on saying `Sink me if you dare' or they would not come here at all. The last thing they would do would be to come here and place themselves in Australian convoys. The threat to our shipping seems to me to be three-fold. The first threat is surface interdiction. A great deal of our trade goes through the archipelago to our north and it would be very easy to block that by refusing passage to ships coming to Australia. As they would be neutral ships, it would be a very high risk policy for the country doing it but it would be a very easy way of blocking shipping coming to or leaving Australia. Rerouting out into the Pacific would be an extremely expensive way to go. Getting iron ore from the north west of Australia round to the south of Australia would be a very expensive business. That is the most obvious way in which our overseas shipping might be interdicted.

If a country were prepared to be more aggressive than that, the obvious way of blocking shipping is mining. Mines are an impersonal weapon and if there is a dispute between two countries and it is announced by one country that a port has been mined, that would be a very strong deterrent to neutral ships going there unless we could persuade them that we had genuinely cleared all the mines. That is why I am glad to see that there is some development going on with our mine hunting and mine clearance capability. I think that threat is quite likely.

Least likely is direct submarine attack on ships. It is personal. The ships sunk would inevitably be neutral and I think it would be an extremely high risk activity for any enemy of ours in a bilateral confrontation to engage in, and in any case the relevance of our forces stopping this is not very great. As I said, the ships are neutral and there is no conceivable way in which they would place themselves in the defence of Australian convoys. The example of the Persian Gulf-the Iran-Iraq war-has often been raised in recent months to show that neutral ships do get attacked. That is perfectly true, but those ships still go there because they get paid to do it. Costs and insurance have gone up but they go there because they are prepared to take the risk. The defensive measures of the Government of Iran are not in any way relevant. The ships are not going there in Iranian convoys or anything like that; they are going there and taking the risk of being sunk because they are being paid for it. If the risk became higher, they would not go there. We must not draw the wrong conclusions from what is going on in that area.

The final deficiency concerns the submarine program. I have never been satisfied that sufficient consideration was given to the French nuclear powered Ruby class submarine which I think would have been appropriate to Australia. It is about the same size as the submarines we are planning to get and it seems to have the sort of characteristics we need. It has not been looked at seriously by the Navy for reasons that I think are at least partly political. However, I do not think this is a matter that we can change. Contracts are going to be let in the middle of this year and unless the Hawke Government is prepared to perform a major public service by committing hari-kari before then, the contracts will have been signed and we will be obliged to honour them. I am sorry that we will be committed for another 20 years to having non- nuclear powered submarines; nevertheless, I think that is a fact of life.

If we are going to do these extra things that I am suggesting, the question is where might we save. As I said at the outset, we must suggest savings if we are to accept increased expenditure. The first saving could be in the area of fleet bases. I am prepared to accept a fleet base in Western Australia. However, I would say that if there is to be a fleet base there there must be a dry dock under naval control. One cannot afford to have an operational fleet at the whim of industrial disputes. In the same way, the operation of the dry dock at Garden Island should be run by the Navy. It would involve a relatively small number of people. We saw during the visit of HMS Invincible that lack of control made it impossible for the Invincible to use that dock. We could not have a situation where our operational fleet, wanting a brief docking, was held up by an industrial dispute in the dockyard. The control-not the work done-must be under uniformed management.

I am not at all convinced that there is any merit in the proposed move to Jervis Bay. People in Sydney who are pressing for a move of the fleet to Jervis Bay think that the Garden Island dockyard will move. That would cost many billions of dollars and it would not be practical. All that will move will be the operational fleet base. As far as I can see, it will make no real difference to Sydney. The move will be a very expensive one, involving many hundreds of millions of dollars. One matter that is already in train-it is not part of the proposal-is to move the ammunition depot there. That is a good idea. I do not think that people understand why an ammunition depot is required. Ships are normally replenished from a supply ship. An ammunition depot is required so that the ammunition can be landed before a ship goes into dock for overhaul and then collected when the ship comes out of dock. It is a deposit place really rather than anything else. Obviously, it is most inappropriate to have that in a major built-up area as it currently is in Sydney.

The second saving: We must tackle work practices and gross overmanning in our government factories and dockyards. The defence paper talks about doing something. Something has been done, but not nearly enough. We cannot afford the gross waste that is going on in these dockyards and government factories and accept that, because of this gross waste, we cannot have the proper equipment for our fighting forces that we very badly need.

Finally, in order to make the necessary savings, we must consider whether we need the Army at the size it is. I have never been persuaded that the regular division would ever be committed to battle. The overheads of the Army have always seemed excessive to me. To make a more mobile, responsive and better equipped Army we must, at the same time, consider whether we can afford from within our resources to have the number of men we have. I believe that that would be a tough decision but one we probably have to take to balance out whether the Defence Force as a whole is properly equipped, properly organised and able to do effectively the things we might have to do on our own.

I said at the outset that we support the broad thrust of the defence White Paper. Its development has been going on for many years-from 1976 when a defence White Paper was produced by the Fraser Government. I entirely agree that our Defence Force, which in efficiency terms is second to none, must be organised and equipped for the roles that it might have to perform on our own.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McIntosh Sen G.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —The bringing down of the 1987 defence policy information paper signals to us the end of the Brisbane Line mentality which has pervaded defence thinking and practice in Australia for many long and weary years. It commits us to the defence of Australia, through the defence of the north, from a threat which can come to Australia only through the north. Although no such threat is envisaged at this time, it would be foolish not to acknowledge it as a future possibility.

SPEECH.PARA: The paper recognises that the most positive aspect of our defence capabilities lies in our geographical position-the fact that our northern shores present a most inhospitable aspect to any potential future invader. But at the same time it recognises that a large and important part of our national assets is to be found in that region and is vulnerable to low or medium level attacks. Planning a defence strategy on this basis can only be described as sensible. The proposal to shift part of our naval capabilities from eastern Australia to the west and the north, an enhanced submarine capacity, the provision of greater battlefield mobility for the army, and the Jindalee over the horizon radar system are just part of the Government's commitment to defending the nation as a whole and not just the triangle which lies between Brisbane and Melbourne, and as such is to be commended. At this stage I prefer to reserve my judgment on the proposed satellite communications station in Western Australia. It could be that spying outside our own area of strategic interests could be carrying the new policy of `defence in depth' too far. This is not to say that I would not be pleased to get some real information, for a change, on the French activities on Kerguelen Island.

Secondly, this White Paper nails down the lid of the coffin of forward defence strategy as a viable defence option for Australia. This strategy was delivered a death blow with the withdrawal of the Australian forces from Vietnam in the 1970s. May it rest in peace. This is not to say that there is no possibility that in future Australian defence forces will not be committed outside our immediate area, but this commitment will be only incidental to the major requirement of the paper-that first and foremost we will be capable of defending ourselves. It will be this capacity to be self-reliant which will have the first priority.

The orientation is towards self-defence, not forward defence. From my reading of the paper it would appear that defence co-operation within the area is more of a diplomatic than a strategic initiative. The tabling statement of the Minister for Resources and Energy (Senator Gareth Evans) emphasises the Government's views on defence co-operation with New Zealand, the South Pacific island states and Papua New Guinea. It mentions also our older established relations with the nations of South East Asia. It is these latter defence relationships which still pose important moral and political questions for Australians.

In the last years of President Marcos's rule, questions were raised in Australia about our military aid to the Philippines. Even though the actual amounts which were expended were small, the symbolism of our association with the Philippines military was powerful. The White Paper suggests that our major defence concerns in the Philippines today are the New People's Army insurgency and the future of the American bases at Clark and Subic Bay. This view clearly suggests that Australia intends to continue military aid to the Philippines in its present form. If so, the Government can expect to be further questioned about the wisdom of that course.

On a much larger scale has been our military aid to Indonesia. The White Paper says that a stable Indonesia is important to our security and that Australia needs to maintain a constructive defence relationship with that country. This is not new. It repeats the long-standing conventional wisdom which has underpinned the policies of successive Australian governments for the last 20 years. What this has traditionally meant is that Australia has essentially defended and supported, through diplomatic silence or direct military and economic aid, repressive government practices in Indonesia. This has been done in the interests of `stability'.

There is considerable sensitivity in Australia about Indonesia. Some of it is ill informed and some of it is a racist hangover from the officially sponsored anti-Sukarno campaigns of the early 1960s. The last thing we need in the ongoing discussion of our defence needs is a repeat of the Indonesia threat atmosphere of that time.

The third area of the paper on which I wish to comment concerns the preservation of our part in the Western alliance. This preservation, I must state, is in accordance with the will of the majority of the people of Australia. Whether this is in their best interests is arguable. There has been a long history in this country of reliance on, and faith in, larger and more powerful allies. First it was the United Kingdom and then, since World War II, the United States.

Irrational perceptions of threats and a misguided belief that great and powerful friends would unfailingly come to our aid in any circumstances continue to exist today in the Australian community. These ideas continue to be promoted by sections of the media, academia and the coalition parties and have been a very real barrier to an honest, informed and rational debate on how we can best defend ourselves. The Dibb Review of Australia's Defence Capabilities was clear on the limits to the support we can expect from outside. On page 46, the report says:
. . . there are potential situations where we would not expect the United States to commit combat forces on our behalf and where we need a demonstrably independent combat capability.

On the ANZUS Treaty itself, Mr Dibb was also quite explicit. He said: `The ANZUS Treaty provides for consultation in the first instance'. Mr Dibb says, and I emphasise this: `There are no guarantees inherent in it'. None of this is new. Anyone who has read the ANZUS Treaty knows that this is the case. Anyone who has watched developments in United States policy, particularly since the so-called Guam doctrine was declared in 1969, knows that the United States expects-I repeat, expects-its allies to be primarily responsible for their own defence. Paragraph 1.25 of the White Paper reinforces this aspect. I think that the paper brought down by the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley) certainly shows that we intend to try to be capable of defending ourselves. It is the policy of self-reliance which is the main thrust of this White Paper and as such is in accordance with the requirements of the alliance. I commend this 1987 White Paper, as presented by the Minister of Defence, Kim Beazley. I believe that the Senate as a whole should adopt such a paper.
Debate (on motion by Senator Reid) adjourned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to speak briefly in the adjournment debate on the subject of Afghanistan because tomorrow is a day that is generally commemorated around the world as Afghanistan Day. It was initially proclaimed by President Reagan in 1983, being the first day of the Islamic spring, and since that time it has been a focal point for very many members of the Afghan community around the world. I think it is instructive that this country should take note of that fact because there are significant Afghan communities in both Melbourne and Sydney. Certainly in Melbourne since 1983 there has been an annual commemoration of the event and in Melbourne this evening there will be an occasion to mark the day.

SPEECH.PARA: I did want to make a couple of remarks. One is in relation to the humanitarian aspect of the refugee intake. The figures for the last financial year show that only 276 refugees have been taken into this country. In view of the fact that very many of those already here have very high academic and commercial qualifications, it seems anomalous, to say the least, that the Government has been so niggardly about the size of the intake, especially in view of the fact that Afghanis represent the largest group of refugees in the world. There are 3 1/2 million to 4 million Afghan refugees in Pakistan and about 800,000 to one million in Iran out of a total population of around 15 million to 18 million. So in terms of the devastation of the population one can almost equate what has happened in Afghanistan with what happened in East Timor as a result of the Indonesian intervention. Rather than simply talk in terms of Afghanistan as the Soviet Union's Vietnam, I think we should look at it from the perspective of those who have been unfortunate enough either to reside there or who have been forced to exit from the country.

I firstly urge the Australian Government to give much more compassionate consideration to a refugee intake in view of the fact that those already here have proved to be very reliable and worthwhile citizens who have a lot to contribute to this country. I have not come across very many of them who are unemployed and they certainly do not seem to shirk from working at more than one job.

The other aspect which I think is of significance is the neglect by the Australian Government of the whole question of Afghanistan. It is clear that the Minister for Foreign Affairs (Mr Hayden) has been taken in by the public relations propaganda of the Soviet leader, Mr Gorbachev, who claimed only in November last year that a withdrawal of Soviet troops was not far away. This year a visit by Mr Shevardnadze, the Foreign Minister, to Kabul resulted in his saying that he was very anxious to ensure a political settlement in this calendar year.

Nothing really has happened apart from a unilateral ceasefire which then resulted in some 12,000 troops being deployed to the eastern border region. There was quite a degree of bloodshed and dispersion of residents in those areas which was obviously a result of an unwillingness on the part of the Mujahedeen, the resistance guerrilla fighters, to accept the bona fides of the Soviet regime. I think their judgment is probably better than that of the Australian Government.

The Soviet Union has, I think, mastered a new technique very quickly. It is now a propaganda, public relations oriented government. No doubt it is much more conscious of world opinion in this area. I believe that the Australian Government has shamefully neglected its responsibilities in terms of moral persuasion. There are initiatives that could have been taken and have not yet been taken. The most that can be said by the Department or the Minister is that he has raised the question of Afghanistan with Mr Shevardnadze on his recent visit and in the event that there is a Soviet troop withdrawal, Australia would be prepared to offer its services as a member of an observer force. I do not regard that as good enough. I believe that there are initiatives that we could take, both in the General Assembly of the United Nations and elsewhere. I regard the formula that the Foreign Minister uses as utterly specious-that we do not recognise the Government of Afghanistan and, therefore, our communications should be directed through multilateral channels.

It is quite clear that the Soviet Union pulls the strings and intends to continue to do so. There is, therefore, no reason why we could not be outspoken in our condemnation of the original invasion and the very slow progress that is being made towards the troop withdrawal. The estimates that I think are reliably accepted are that there are some 120,000 troops. The war has now entered its eighth year and it is clear that the Soviets realise they are quagmired in an unwinnable war. They will not withdraw unless forced to do so by the weight of international opinion. The cosmetic leadership changes announced last year should fool no one. The fact of the matter is that one brutal puppet has been replaced by another. The current leader, Major-General Naji Bullah, has impeccable credentials when it comes to having organised the secret police in Afghanistan, but offers no promise of any amelioration of the conditions in that country. To suggest that Karmal was forced to retire on the grounds of poor health is simply a sick joke of the highest order. I would have thought that it is not a basis on which we should rely.

I therefore urge the Government and the Foreign Minister to take positive action in the field of international diplomacy. Mr Hayden is fond of saying that in the world of international affairs words are bullets. It is about time he discharged a few loud salvos in the direction of the Soviet Union. To date he has fired only blanks. In view of the fact that very little progress is being made and that the Geneva talks have been adjourned until May, I believe that one way of ensuring that they do not simply stall indefinitely is for countries in the Western region to take initiatives. I instance the deafening silence of the Minister on the occasion of the seventh anniversary of the Soviet invasion on 27 December last. Australia said absolutely nothing and yet the Governments of the United States of America, Britain, France, West Germany and China all marked the occasion by issuing strong statements of condemnation. I therefore find it difficult to understand the Government's lack of concern. I do not know whether it is because the Afghan community is relatively small, whether it is because it does not have much electoral clout or whether Mr Hayden is simply interested in big nation power plays and is prepared to disregard the range of atrocities and physical intimidation that is constantly being perpetrated in that unfortunate country. I therefore would urge that this day not pass unnoted. There is an opportunity for those in this country who are concerned with human rights to show, by urging the Foreign Minister, that Australia is not prepared to remain silent in this important area.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
